BLUEPRINT
Official MCP

Radix UI is a low-level UI component library that provides a set of unstyled and accessible building blocks for creating custom user interfaces in React applications. It focuses on providing the primitives and patterns for building accessible and composable UI components.

Use Radix UI when you want full control over the styling and behavior of your UI components and prefer to build your own design system from scratch. It's suitable for projects where you need a high degree of customization and want to prioritize accessibility.

Avoid Radix UI if you prefer a component library with pre-built themes and styles that require minimal customization. Also, if you're not comfortable with building your own design system and handling accessibility concerns, Radix UI might not be the best choice.
Radix Themes only works with React
Radix Themes has 37 components, 28 of them are unique – for example radio and radio group are considered as same.
Radix has 2 themes, colors are customizable but either for light or dark themes.
Does not support more than 2 themes at the same time

Radix Themes has 72 third-party dependencies. Using more third-party dependencies increases the risk of security vulnerabilities, compatibility problems, and long-term maintenance headaches from deprecated packages.
Radix Themes CSS file is not available on CDN
Radix Themes does not use semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
Radix Themes requires changing JavaScript props one by one at build time to do design token customization
Radix Themes requires a Node.js environment
Radix Themes does not provide micro CSS files for each component
Radix Themes uses wide-gamut P3 colors
Radix Themes customizations requires changing JavaScript props at build time
Radix Themes doesn not use native CSS nesting

daisyUI is a component library for Tailwind CSS that provides pre-designed components with theming capabilities. It is framework-agnostic, meaning it can be used in any web project, and it doesn't ship any JavaScript to the browser.

Use daisyUI when you want to rapidly prototype or build a project with a consistent design system based on Tailwind CSS. It's well-suited for projects where you need a large variety of customizable components and theme options without writing a lot of custom CSS.

Avoid daisyUI if you need highly specific or unique component designs that deviate significantly from the pre-designed styles. Also, if you prefer to build all components from scratch for maximum control over every detail, daisyUI might not be the best choice.
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 63 components, 59 of them are unique – for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI uses semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
How daisyUI and Radix approach building UI components

Radix performs well on GitHub. daisyUI shows higher numbers in terms of stars. The toolkit provided by Radix is useful. daisyUI's component toolkit is larger than Radix's. daisyUI requires no external dependencies to function
The toolkit provided by Radix is useful. daisyUI's component toolkit is larger than Radix's.
Switching between daisyUI's 35 themes is straightforward using CSS or using HTML data attributes. This process might be different or more involved in Radix.
Radix performs well on GitHub. daisyUI shows higher numbers in terms of stars. Radix is widely used. daisyUI's usage, measured by weekly downloads, surpasses Radix's
Radix performs well on GitHub. daisyUI shows higher numbers in terms of stars.
Radix is widely used. daisyUI's usage, measured by weekly downloads, surpasses Radix's.
daisyUI requires no external dependencies to function.
If you're familiar with Radix, it's interesting to see how daisyUI handles components differently, relying on Tailwind utility classes and CSS variables.
